subject: Re: [junit] Testing object instantiated by Spring
msgSnippet: Generally we recommend that in unit tests you don t even use the context. If the code is written in a proper IoC style, it should be able to be hooked up
messageBody:
Generally we recommend that in unit tests you don't even use the
context. If the code is written in a proper IoC style, it should be able
to be hooked up easily without the context. On the other hand, when you
get to integration style tests where a number of classes are working
together, using a context may make things easier.

What works pretty nicely in this case too is to combine multiple xml fragments to make up the context, with the tests mixing different fragments than the production use, so that you can do things like using a different DataSource than you would in the real container.

Also, take a look at the helper classes here:
http://www.springframework.org/docs/api/org/springframework/test/package-summary.html
they can save some decent amount of work... These classes are available as part of the spring-mock.jar.


Colin
(core Spring developer)



Tambascio, Larry wrote:

>I think you could do either. Using Spring for tests may require a different
>context for unit tests, perhaps. But there's nothing wrong with manually
>setting up your class using the new operator. The risk is in the
>duplication (in your tests, are you setting it up exactly as Spring will?).
>I'd probably start with using new, and if things start to get complex, then
>figure out how to use Spring (which isn't that hard I believe).
>
>-Larry
